awd_titl_txt: Structural and Dynamical Determinants of Influenza Transmissibility
awd_abstract_narration:
Both seasonal and pandemic influenza have been responsible for millions of deaths worldwide.  The persistence of seasonal influenza strains costs between 3,000 and 49,000 lives annually in the United States alone.  The project aims to use Blue Waters to run simulations of the influenza virus to explain flu transmissibility.  These simulations will be of a very large scale, involving over 200 million atoms, and are expected to provide unprecedented insights into the mechanisms of influenza virulence and drug resistance.  In addition, simulations will set the stage for the longer-term goal of developing an atomic-level understanding of the influenza infection process, leading to new pathways for pharmacological intervention.

The project has used molecular dynamics (MD) simulations of the individual influenza membrane glycoproteins hemagglutinin (HA) and neuraminidase (NA) to identify experimentally validated antiviral compounds that bind to new glycoprotein pockets never before captured by experimental techniques.  However, influenza glycoproteins are components of a much larger virion surface that collectively participates in host recognition and infection processes.   The surface glycoprotein distributions and their decoration with glycans poses many interesting unanswered questions related to the roles of HA, NA, glycans, and substrate (and substrate mimicks) play in the viral infection and assembly process.  Additionally, the functional balance of HA, which binds to host-cell receptors, and NA, which abrogates receptor binding via cleavage of terminal sialic-acid residues, has not yet been fully characterized  The project request time to run two whole virion simulations: (1) H1N1 with glycans attached to key glycolysation sites on HA and NA and (2) with sialic acid bound in the sialic acid binding sites (mimicking a substrate bound complex). With the addition of the glycans and substrates, both systems will consist of over 200 million atoms.  The simulations will for the first time combine large-scale, subcellular / cellular level modeling at atomic detail with Markov state model theory; effectively aggregating the many copies of the individual glycoproteins into one statistics based network of states type model that enables it to extract long timescale dynamics from the short time scale simulations.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Influenza A virus (IAV) is an enveloped negative-strand RNA virus responsible for a contagious human illness affecting respiratory tracts commonly referred to as “flu”. Aside from annual seasonal outbreaks causing significant morbidity and mortality, IAV can unpredictably undergo random reassortments of its segmented genome that may result in devastating worldwide pandemics. In this concerning scenario, the most critical mutations are usually found in two membrane glycoproteins, hemagglutinin (HA) and neuraminidase (NA), which exhibit on their surface a heterogeneous population of glycans implicated in numerous viral processes, such as infectivity, pathogenicity, transmissibility, protein cooperativity, and small molecule binding. When examining H1N1 flu strains emerged over the last century, the number of glycosites exposed by HA and NA changes at regular temporal intervals and alters IAV antigenic properties. This, among others, is in fact one of the reasons why IAV represents a relentless health threat requiring seasonal vaccines to be updated every few years. Related to this evolutionary pressure, experiments aiming at deciphering how minute modifications in the glycoprofiles can impact on IAV functions are strongly hampered by glycans high variability, flexibility and small size. However, computer simulations and modeling techniques, assisted by a continuous growth of hardware and software technologies, constitute a viable solution to tackle these open questions. Thus, to address these open questions in flu biology, we have integrated various kinds of experimental data (e.g., x-ray crystallography, cryoelectron tomography, mass spectrometry, etc.) with computational approaches to model the entire IAV viral envelope, with its full glycosylation profile, at the atomic level. With the help of this powerful “computational microscope”, and taking advantage of the Blue Waters high-performance petascale supercomputer, we were able to build and simulate a realistic all-atom viral envelope of the A/Michigan/45/2015(H1N1) strain. Our work explored why mutations, which occurred within the antigenic site located on the HA head of this 2015 outbreak, resulted to be so dramatic that in 2017 the World Health Organization needed to change the vaccine composition to target this specific strain. Overall, through this computational approach, in the context of an unceasing antigenic drift imposed by the intense antibody pressure, our project elucidated the key roles of glycans in IAV biology and their impact on the immune response escape.  In addition, these simulations contained over 160 million atoms and thus broke new ground for the size, scale, and complexity of biophysical simulations, providing an innovative framework for the study of future pandemic infectious disease outbreaks.
